koan.name: findAboutKoansFile
koan.lesson: You need to open the file ${file_path}${file_name}.java. There should be a method starting with @Koan called ${method_name}, look within it for your first lesson. Once conquered, run again for your next lesson.

koan.name: definitionOfKoanCompletion
koan.lesson: A koan is considered complete when it no longer throws an exception. Often there is more than one way to solve a koan, but only one correct way. This is often hinted at within the koan itself, or the comments appearing here.

koan.name: assertBooleanTrue
koan.lesson: The __ are an attempt to communicate the need to fill in an answer. Judging by context, what should __ be replaced with?

koan.name: assertBooleanFalse
koan.lesson: Like the prior koan. Ponder if you will, the power of simple assertions when verifying an object's behavior.

koan.name: assertNullObject
koan.lesson: A keyword in java to represent an unitialized reference is 'null'. There are times when something should be null, and this assertion can prove that.

koan.name: assertNotNullObject
koan.lesson: Sometimes you merely wish to assert an object is not null. This assertion should be used sparingly, often a more specific assertion is appropriate.

koan.name: assertEqualsWithDescriptiveMessage
koan.lesson: Like the prior assertions, only this one invokes equals method on the 2nd to last argument, in this case, 1. This will blow up if the last two arguments are not .equal(...)

koan.name: assertSameInstance
koan.lesson: An object may equal another object, but it will never be the same as another object. Two references to the same object is not the same as two references to two equal objects.

koan.name: assertNotSameInstance
koan.lesson: Notice the same instance has been reassigned. Both same and sameReference refer to the same Integer instance. If sameReference were a new Object() of any type [hint!] this would pass.

koan.name: objectEqualsNull
koan.lesson: An Object instance should NEVER equal null keyword. This applies to all subclasses (everything exception primitives subclass Object).

koan.name: objectEqualsSelf
koan.lesson: An Object instance should equal itself. This too applies to all subclasses of Object.

koan.name: objectIdentityEqualityIsTrueWhenReferringToSameObject
koan.lesson: An object should equal itself, even if referenced from another variable name.

koan.name: subclassesEqualsMethodIsLooserThanDoubleEquals
koan.lesson: Integer, and many other classes implement equals logically, in other words, they compare properties of each other and not just identity.

koan.name: doubleEqualsOperatorEvalutesToTrueOnlyWithSameInstance
koan.lesson: Double equals operator (==) does not invoke equal, it will evaluate to true if both references refer to the same object or primitive.

koan.name: doubleEqualsOperatorEvalutesToFalseWithDifferentInstances
koan.lesson: The inverse of the prior koan, though two objects may be logically equal, they are not referencing the same object.

koan.name: objectToString
koan.lesson: How to identify an object at in string form. Should be overridden in any objects with internal state. Default to string is classname of the instance followed by its hashCode in base 16 (hexadecimal).

koan.name: toStringConcatenates
koan.lesson: Java 's string concatenation syntax utilizes addition operator to splice a string with virtually anything.

koan.name: toStringIsTestedForNullWhenInvokedImplicitly
koan.lesson: String concatenation implicitly invokes toString on Objects, unless they are null. Notice no NullPointerException is thrown.

koan.name: overridenMethodsMayReturnSubtype
koan.lesson: An overridden method may return a subtype of the return type for the method being overridden. Look at the javadoc for java.util.Collection or java.util.List - it will reveal how to eliminate this type cast.

koan.name: arraysDoNotConsiderElementsWhenEvaluatingEquality
koan.lesson: Arrays utilize reference equality, they do not consider elements when determining equality.

koan.name: cloneEqualityIs_NotRespected
koan.lesson: The general contract of clone is that: Object a == new Object(); a != a.clone(); a.equals(a.clone()). Array instances DO NOT honor this contract, despite implementing Cloneable.

koan.name: anArraysHashCodeMethodDoesNotConsiderElements
koan.lesson: Likewise with hashcode, an array instance's hashCode is that of the array, it does not incorporate elements.

koan.name: arraysHelperClassEqualsMethodConsidersElementsWhenDeterminingEquality
koan.lesson: The Arrays.equals(...) method DOES evaluate elements when determining equality. This is called 'Logical Equality'.

koan.name: arraysHelperClassHashCodeMethodConsidersElementsWhenDeterminingHashCode
koan.lesson: Likewise with hashCode, the Arrays.hashCode(...) method DOES consider elements when determining hashCode.

koan.name: arraysAreMutable
koan.lesson: Arrays are always mutable, even when declared final. The final declaration prevents reassignment, but does nothing for elements.

koan.name: arraysAreIndexedAtZero
koan.lesson: Arrays contain elements which are indexed by a number starting with zero.

koan.name: arrayIndexOutOfBounds
koan.lesson: Array instances blow up when referencing an index that doesn't exist.

koan.name: arrayLengthCanBeChecked
koan.lesson: It is often necessary to check the length of an array to ensure an index is valid. This is easy with the array's length property.

koan.name: addPrimativesToCollection
koan.lesson: Before Java 5, we had to convert primatives to add to collections

koan.name: addPrimativesToCollectionWithAutoBoxing
koan.lesson: With AutoBoxing, we can _cheat_

koan.name: migrateYourExistingCodeToAutoBoxingWithoutFear
koan.lesson: With AutoBoxing, we can intermix as well

koan.name: allPrimativesCanBeAutoboxed
koan.lesson: All primatives can be autoboxed

koan.name: simpleAnonymousMock
koan.lesson: How can this pass without touching the ClassUnderTest?
